head_text.subj: EXT. BOARDWALK AMUSEMENT PARK. BOTTLE TOSS BOOTH. NIGHT

text: It’s 1986. A colorful vibrant energy. Pedestrians walk along the boardwalk past game booths and souvenir stands as a ROLLE COASTER SCREAMS by overhead. ADELAIDE (9, African American) wears a “Hands Across Amer T-shirt, and her hair up in pigtails. She holds a candied apple, and watches, her father, RUSSELL (33, African American) hurl a baseball and TOPPLES a pyramid of bottle a “Bottle-Pyramid” booth. He’s clearly in a bad mood and takes it out on the bottles. RAYNE, Adelaide’s mother, (30, African American) CLAPS obligatorily.
The booth attendant, DANNY, a stoner, feigns excitement. Judging by their physical energies, Rayne and Russell had huge fight earlier. Russell picks up a beer.
Great shot. You put some heat on that.
Thanks. I guess I missed my chance to go pro.
You can get a prize from the second level or keep goin’ for a prize from the third level.
What you think, Addy? Should we stop or keep goin’? Adelaide looks at Rayne.
Don’t look at me; it’s your birthday. Adelaide points to a T-shirt.
I want that one.
Yeah alright. That one. Russell takes the shirt, then takes Adelaide’s candied ap and hands it to Rayne. RUSSELL (CONT’D) Here... Moments later...

head_text.subj: EXT. BOARDWALK AMUSEMENT PARK. MAIN STRIP. NIGHT

text: Adelaide lags behind Rayne and Russell as they stroll dow the strip. She wears a new oversized “Michael Jackson's Thriller” t-shirt.
(To Russell) That shirt better not give her nightmares.
In trouble for buyin’ my daughter a shirt. That’s a new one.
She got scared when it was on TV. You'd know that if you were around.
Who let her watch it?
I wasn’t scared.
You hid your eyes when the people came out the ground.
No.
(To Rayne) I need another beer. Adelaide turns her head and sees a drunk sailor, TED spil his drink on his white uniform.
Mmmm Hmmm.
I can’t have a beer now?
You can do whatever you want.
Okay then. The ROLLERCOASTER RUMBLES BY again; Adelaide watches it. screams startle her a little. They pass fast food RUSSELL (CONT’D) What about The Dipper? Hey Addy, you wanna try it?
You know she’s not big enough, and I sure as Hell am not going on that thing. a table where two teenagers, MANDY and DOWNEY, eat like pigs.
Moments later, Adelaide, Rayne, and Russell arrive at the Whac-A-Mole booth.

head_text.subj: EXT. BOARDWALK AMUSEMENT PARK. WHAC-A-MOLE. NIGHT

text: ‘Whac-A-Mole’! This is my game. (To the booth attendant, TROY) How many tickets, four?
Yeah. Russell slams four tickets down, grabs the tethered malle and starts playing.
Addy, come to the bathroom.
I don’t have to go.
Russ, will you watch your daughter, please?

I'm watching... He’s not. He’s playing Whac-A-Mole. Rayne heads off. Adel watches Russell for a moment before her attention turns t the ocean. She walks towards the edge of the boardwalk. A young homeless man, YOUNG FERDIE, lurks by the wooden staircase leading to the beach. He’s clutching a cardboar sign with a bible verse scrawled across it. “Jeremiah 11: is written boldly and Young Adelaide stares at the number as she passes him. He looks right at her. Two teens, GLEN and NANCY, flirtatiously play “Rock Paper Scissors.” They keep landing on the same combination over over.
Oh my god
That's impossible. They do it again. They land on scissors.
What the hell?
How are you doing that?
I’m not doing anything. You are.

head_text.subj: EXT. BEACH NEAR THE BOARDWALK. NIGHT

text: Adelaide walks down the stairs, and onto the beach where few teenagers act wild by a small campfire. Adelaide passes by the teenagers as she walks towards the water’s edge.

head_text.subj: EXT. BEACH NEAR THE WATER. NIGHT

text: Moments later... She approaches the shoreline and scans the dark horizon. the distance, a large cloud erupts in silent lightning. A a breath, she turns back towards the boardwalk. One attraction faces her on the beach level underneath th boardwalk. It’s called “SHAMAN’S VISION QUEST”, a Native American mystical themed funhouse with an entrance that f the water. The facade is painted to resemble a forest wit colorful images of spirit-animals and a large Shaman who glares, pointing his finger directly at Adelaide. Signs n the arched doorway read “GET LOST” and “FIND YOURSELF.”
Adelaide walks toward the Vision Quest portal.

head_text.subj: EXT. BEACH NEAR THE BOARDWALK. NIGHT

text: She drops the candied apple which falls onto the sand. As Adelaide gets near the entrance, a THUP or two of thick r drops hit the sand. The crowd over at the boardwalk MURMU
Adelaide enters just as the rain hits full on.

head_text.subj: INT. VISION QUEST. FOREST ROOM. NIGHT

text: Adelaide enters The Vision Quest, and goes down a hallway made to feel like a magical walk through a dark forest.

The walls are dressed and painted like woods, with the occasional eerily pleasant deer, rabbits and eagles. A CACOPHONOUS RECORDING OF NATURE SOUNDS plays over hidden speakers. A cast-plastic owl on a branch pounces out from a dark crevice startling Adelaide with a “HOO HOO”. The owl emit HISS OF PRESSURIZED AIR and returns to its starting point Adelaide calms herself, and continues into the maze.

head_text.subj: INT. VISION QUEST. HALL OF MIRRORS. NIGHT

text: Adelaide enters a room that’s still forest themed but als covered in mirrors. She walks past several distorted reflections. A short one, a weird one, and a weirder one. With a RUMBLE OF LIGHTNING the lights go out, and the FOR NOISE STOPS. What was kinda eerie when lit becomes downri terrifying when dark. The only light comes from the glowing red exit sign. She walks towards it but hits a mirror. She looks up. The “EX sign appears forwards and backwards, over and over again infinite reflections. Adelaide reaches her hands out and tries to make her way down the mirrored wall. She begins whistling “ITSY BITSY SPIDER” again to make he feel at ease, but she stops in near panic when a WHISTLE the halls overtakes hers. Somebody, somewhere in the mirr labyrinth is whistling in an attempt to emulate her tune. Something her size SCURRIES QUICKLY across the hallway. Adelaide backs up almost against a mirror. She slowly beg to turn 180 degrees to face the mirror behind her, but HE REFLECTION DOESN'T TURN!!! This isn’t a mirror, its the b of another identical girl's head. Black.
Closeup on a red wet rabbit’s eye. “ug” MUSIC: A CHILDREN’S CHOIR HUMS A DARK ANTHEM IN A STRANGE

head_text.subj: LANGUAGE. THE SONG IS MELODIC AND BRIGHT. HOPEFUL, BUT AL

text: We slowly pull away. The rabbit sits in a brass cage agai a tiled wall. We pull out to reveal more and more rabbits cages stacked one on top of the other.

We look out the rear window past stick figure stickers depicting father, mother, daughter and son. The Wilson's travels through a rural road where woods and beach meet. EXT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. DAY The Wilson's car arrives. INT. THE WILSON’S CAR. DAY ADELAIDE WILSON (African American, now 34) wakes up in th passenger seat she looks over at GABE WILSON (African American, 34), a large man with glasses who thinks he’s a cooler than he is, in the driver’s seat. Gabe holds his finger in front of his mouth like “Shhhhh”. Adelaide know where this is going. They look at the kids asleep in the back, ZORA WILSON, (African American, 13) and JASON WILSO (African American, 11).
(yelling) We made it!!!! The kids wake up in panic. Gabe LAUGHS.
Why???? Noooo.

‘Cause y’all sleep too much. EXT. WILSON'S BAYSIDE HOUSE. DRIVEWAY. DAY. The Wilsons emerge. Adelaide looks down the road ponderou Jason starts wandering off. Jason goes to the back of the car to get his bag. Zora ch her phone.
Wifi isn’t working.  10.
You don’t need the internet. Out here you’ve got... the “Outernet.”
Good one.
Hey, little man! Bags inside first. Jason runs back and Gabe hands him his bag.
Can we rewind her?
I don’t think they work like that.

Just one year. She laughs. Gabe kisses her neck real quick and goes insi INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. KITCHEN BREAKFAST TABLE. DAY We pass through the Wilson’s foyer. Hanging on the wall a pictures of Adelaide at different stages of life with Rus and Rayne. There’s one of her at fourteen in ballet class There are also pictures of Zora and Jason with their grandmother.
What do you call a cow with no legs... Ground beef.
(dryly) Ha ha.
Get it? ‘Cause he’s on the ground?
We get it.
You should practice while you're here. ZORA (0.S. Uch, okay.
What..?
What?
Why you got attitude?

(sarcastic) I’m sorry. Yay, track and field. We find the Wilsons eating fast food in the breakfast noo Zora and Gabe power through their food. Jason sits quietl occasionally snapping his right hand. He wears a plastic werewolf mask on his head. Adelaide eats strawberries out a tupperware container. She plays with her food a little. No.
Whoa. Really..? You’re over running now?
You love track and field.
What’s the point?
The Olympics.
I’m not gonna make it into the Olympics.
You can do anything you set your mind to.
Can I drive while we’re up here?
No.
That's what I set my mind to. I set my mind to driving.
Change your mind.  12.
Why not? Jason runs off to his room.
Because we said so. (To Jason) Jason! Finish your food, please!
Cara and Haley drove with parent supervision.
You don’t need to drive when you are an Olympic caliber athlete... You run.
My God.
You should run on the sand.
Why?
‘Cause it’s harder; no traction. You practice on the beach, when you get on solid ground, you’ll take off. Adelaide is caught off guard by the mention of the beach.
We're going to the beach?
Yeah... later... I thought we’d go when we’re settled...
Cool.
What beach?
Santa Cruz. The boardwalk. I told you about this.  13.
No. You didn’t.
Josh and Kitty and the girls’1l be there. Adelaide and Zora share an eye roll.
Do we have to sell grandma's house? Gabe looks to Adelaide before he answers.
Well... It’s not that "we have to”--
--We have to because school is too expensive, and coming here once a year doesn’t make it worth it. Another awkward silence. Jason's constant snapping linger
What are you doing?
It’s a magic trick. I left it here last year.
Okay... Let’s see it. Everyone looks expectantly. Jason snaps again; nothing happens. They look at each other.
This thing is bullshit..
Whoa! Excuse me. Gabe points at Jason.
You cursing at the table now?
(mumbling to Gabe) When you point a finger at someone else, you have three pointing back at you.
What the hell is that supposed to mean?
I think it means you curse at the table too. Gabe grumbles and goes back to eating. Gabe looks
Well it’s four fingers, anyway... Four fingers pointing back at you.
One’s a thumb... and it’s not pointing at you.

Go to your room. at his hand for a second then brushes it off. INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE. DAY Young Adelaide sits intense and still on a sofa. Though t sliver of open door, she can see Russell and Rayne speaki with DR. FOSTER.
I think she has Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.
What...? She wasn’t in Nam’; she got lost for fifteen minutes.
That can be very scary.
We don’t know what happened to her.
So, how do we get her to talk?
I could meet with her once a week.
Mmm hmm. For how long?

I think we need to encourage her to draw, write... dance... anything to help her tell us her story... but we have to be patient. Rayne quietly weeps. Dr. Foster passes her a tissue. Russ goes to touch Rayne but she pulls away. Russell le
I’m gonna have a smoke. aves. PRESENT DAY...

location: WILSON'S BEACH HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. INT

text: Adelaide lays on the couch looking at one of Jason’s rubb spider toys. A real spider climbs across it. Gabe unpacks with a pep in his step in a nearby room.

(On the phone) Yeah, we'll see... Well, that’s a coincidence... Listen... listen... I’m not gonna say anything but “wait for it.” You’ll see.. You’1ll see... INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. FOYER/LIVING ROOM. DAY Gabe finishes his call as Adelaide looks at the spider.
(On the phone) Why would I lie? Alright..? See you soon. He hangs up.
That was Josh. We’1ll leave in an hour.
We just got here.
They stayed an extra day so we could meet up...  16.
Off her reaction.
What? You don’t like Josh and Kitty now?
Eh...
Damn... It’s like that? Okay. Name one thing wrong with Josh and Kit--
--They drink too much.
Okay... Two things.
Gabe...
Zora and the girls get along.
Nope.
What’s the point of a summer home by the beach if you never go to the beach.
There’s a beach just down that hill.
That’s not a beach. It’s a shore. That's a bay. I’m talking about a real beach. Sand; an amusement park; people...
There are weirdos at that beach. Gabe realizes there’s something deeper going on.
Okay... okay. I’1ll cancel... Just sucks... I know Jason was looking forward to it... First time back after grandma died... I think being here is hitting him hard.  17.
(begrudgingly) We leave there before it gets dark.
Yeah. Hell yeah; it’s gonna be fun. He goes for a kiss. She laughs and playfully pushes him a
You don’t have to kiss me. You’re in trouble for later, tho. He heads to the door. She can tell he’s up to something.
Oh you think so?
Oh yes.
Where are you going?
Taking out the trash. I’1l be right back. Gabe hustles out with a mischievous smirk. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Adelaide passes Zora’s room.

Where’s your brother? Zora shrugs. Adelaide opens the basement door. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. DAY Adelaide walks down to the basement. There is a washer, a dryer, and a table for folding laund in front of a mirrored wall. She finds a box and opens it. They are pictures of her as child in a ballerina tutu. There’s also an old stuffed bu  18.

She smiles with melancholic nostalgia. Out of nowhere, “Y Adelaide” spins through the space. This was a mini ballet practice studio. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BATHROOM. DAY Zora enters and shuts the door. She looks in the mirror. leans in examining a blemish when... Jason bursts out of cabinet and scampers out the door. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. DAY Adelaide watches her fourteen-year-old self, “Teen Adelai dance, now with perfect pirouettes. Footsteps thump above INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Jason enters the closet.

The door begins to creak shut, but he puts a toy ambulanc the crack, propping the door open for a sliver of light. Jason pulls his mask down and resumes snapping. After a f unsuccessful snaps, he pauses. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Zora walks down the hallway and nonchalantly bumps the to ambulance into the closet with her heel. The closet door shuts. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Jason grabs the doorknob from inside, jiggling it. It’s locked. INT. THE WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. BASEMENT. DAY Adelaide watches Teen Adelaide dance when Jason SCREAMS upstairs. Adelaide is startled. INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. ZORA'S ROOM. DAY Adelaide passes the open doorway to Zora’s room. She’s pissed.  19.
You can’t help him? Zora is laying on the bed with headphones on. She turns a her mom passes by.
What happened? INT. WILSON’S BAYSIDE HOUSE. HALLWAY. DAY Adelaide opens the closet door. Jason sits there.
Oh baby. That’s why you can’t play in there. Jason’s tears turn to rage.
Didn't this happen last year?
Zora, please... The moment is broken by a DISTANT BUZZ that starts small gets closer.
Hey! The three of them look at each other..

Adelaide, Zora and Jason stand on the dock by their house Gabe, a pillar of pride, stands triumphantly at the steer wheel of a small motor boat that buzzes around in circles beams while Adelaide, Zora and Jason remain thoroughly unimpressed.
Well... What’dya think?! “Craw- Daddy”!
(unimpressed) Wow.
It’s got a cassette player and everything... All it needs is a new coat of paint! They just watch him. He holds up a life preserver.
Hey, “J”, look!. It even came with one of these! The boat engine SPUTTERS TO A HALT. Smoke bellows from it Gabe goes
(to Adelaide) He’s kidding right?
(under her breath) He’s not kidding.
Hold up. He told me how to fix this. to the back of the boat and pounds it with his fist a couple times.
Don’t worry. I got it real cheap!
I would hope so.
She veers a little to the left, so you have to stay on it, but other than that it’s perfect!
You think?
Also, Josh got a boat, so we can do a dual-family voyage.
Ah. I see.
Josh's boat is probably way better.  21.
What?
He said Josh’s boat is probably better.
It’s not a contest. It’s something I thought would be nice for the family.
But will we all fit tho?

Okay, you know what? Y’all are spoiled. The engine starts up again. Gabe almost falls. Adelaide a Zora are amused. INT. WILSON’S CAR. DAY Gabe pouts as he drives through a road lined with redwood trees. The rest of the family chills in their seats. Jaso snaps in the back. Zora reads. Adelaide checks in on Gabe mood.
Did you know this country produces, like twice as much waste per capita as any other country in the developed world? No one responds. Jason looks at her dryly.
I forgot. No one cares about the environment.
Since when did you become such a tree hugger?
I’m not a tree hugger.
I like it. I’m just saying. Zora watches Jason continue to snap.  22.
..-Maybe you could just tell us what’s supposed to happen and we can picture it. He keeps snapping.
I mean, at a certain point--
--Kiss my anus, Zora.
Oh!
What?!? Zora is shocked, and Adelaide tries to hide her smile.
Why are we even talkin’ bout “anuses?”
“Anus” isn’t a curse word.
That doesn’t matter.
Disgusting.
See I would’ve preferred a curse word in this case.
(To Adelaide) I can see you laughing in the mirror. Gabe leans on the horn.

OK, you know what? We don’t always need to be talking. There are families that enjoy silence. The rest of them look around “yeesh”. Adelaide knows her family. She turns on the radio. “I Got Five On It” by Lun is on. Gabe’s mood immediately lifts.  23.
“I got Five on it...” He grooves in his seat. Zora and Jason share a look.
What does “I got five on it” mean?
It’s about drugs.
It’s a dope song; don’t do drugs.
Jason. Get it in rhythm. She starts snapping to the rhythm. Jason follows along. Gabe loosens up and sit dances singing along.
“I got five on it...” Zora and Adelaide share a look through the rearview mirro Adelaide shrugs. Zora rolls her eyes in pleasant conceit.

The car drives past more redwood trees. INT. WILSON’S CAR. TRANSITIONAL ROAD. DAY They emerge from the wood-lined road and overlook downtow Santa Cruz’s amusement park, boardwalk and beach. The rollercoaster looms menacingly in the distance. Adelaide hides her apprehension as they head towards the scene of her past horror.
The car arrives at a crosswalk. A CROSSING GUARD steps ou front of the car and stops them. They wait while a line o leave sailors crosses the street in front of the Wilson’s car.
Why can’t I drive in the parking lot?  24.
You’re not old enough.
I’m not talking to you.
Hmm, let me think about that for a second... no.
Why?

Because I cherish my life. As the sailors pass, Adelaide watches the town go by and remains preoccupied with thought. FLASHBACK... INT. RAYNE’S CAR. NIGHT Rayne drives away from the rainy beach. We can’t quite he words but can tell that Russell is drunk. He and Rayne ar Young Adelaide sits in the backseat in total shock. PRESENT DAY... INT. WILSON’S CAR. ROAD TO AMUSEMENT PARK. DAY
Ahhh. Damn it. Adelaide snaps out of her daydream. They’ve just turned a corner and ended up stuck behind an ambulance and cop car that block the street.
Oh my God. A couple of COPS are taking statements from locals on the sidewalk who witnessed the incident at hand. Two EMTs loa unconscious bleeding homeless man into the ambulance.
Don’t look. Don’t look.
You gotta be kidding me. A cop waves the car past. Jason watches the man.  25.

head_text.subj: EXT. BEACH. BY THE BOARDWALK. DAY

text: The Wilsons, having parked, step onto the sand carrying folding chairs and other beach gear. As they walk, Adelai fights the urge to look behind her. Eventually she steals nonchalant glance back in the direction of where the ‘Vis Quest’ was when she was a child. The attraction is still there, but it’s name has been changed to ‘Merlin’s Forest It still has the same “FIND YOURSELF” sign, but the Shama has been replaced with an old white wizard who still poin his finger outwards like a bizarro Uncle Sam.
Was that guy dead?
Who?
The guy in the ambulance?
Ambulance means he’s alive, right? Jason, unsure, nods and starts snapping again.

They arrive at the Tyler family’s beach set-up: umbrella, chairs, and a stocked cooler already set up in tidy order JOSH TYLER (Caucasian 40) KITTY TYLER (Caucasian 40) sit. Josh and Kitty are both a couple drinks in. The Tyler twins LINDSEY and BECCA (Caucasian 14) play by water.
Ay!
Yay!
You said 2:30! Where’s your efficiency, man? Efficiency!
We got held up.
I'm kidding, don’t worry Hey girl. about it.  26.
We made it.
Oh my God. Zora, you’ve gotten so big! You look so pretty?
(Hates the compliment) Hey, Jason. You want a beer? Thanks.
Um...
(To Zora) (To Jason) Lindsey and Becca will be No. The answer is “no.” happy to see you. (To Josh) Please give me a couple more years.

(to Becca and Lindsey) (To Jason) Guys, look who’s here! I kid. Here’s a soda. Becca flies a kite, Lindsey does cartwheels. They wave. Z gives her mom an “I hate these bitches” look before walki over to them. (CONT'D)

Hi, Jason! Jason waves shyly as he walks off. LATER... The two families chill on the beach. Zora sits near the t who practice gymnastics. Jason plays nearby in the sand. Gabe and Josh pal around, pouring beers into plastic cups cracking each other up.
Have you taken her on her maiden voyage yet?
Just rode her home. But we’re gonna do the family thing soon.  27.
Cool. We could do a double excursion.
Yeah, I mean, it’s small, but it’s a real classic design.
Hey, it’s not about the size of the boat...
..-The fuck outta here. Josh laughs.
Kitty! Kitty who is talking to Adelaide looks over.
You hear Gabe got a boat?
Oh? Cool.
He says “it’s small.” I said, “It’s not the size of the boat...”
(to Josh) Wow. You thought that bared repeating. .?
He did though. He really did.
Screw all of you. Adelaide glances back again still distracted by the ‘Merl Forest’. Kitty clocks it.
‘Merlin’s Forest’...?
I think that changed. It used to be called ‘Vision Quest.’
Oh, how culturally insensitive of them...
Yeah. Totally.
Addy, beer, wine, vodka cran? Mimosa? I got everything.
Do you have water?
Um... I’ve got ice. 28. He hands her a cup of ice. Then passes kitty a drink. He pulls her drink away before giving it to her. practical joke.
I hate you. (to Adelaide) It never stops. I honestly think about murdering him sometimes. Adelaide laughs.
So nothing’s new.
Actually. Since you asked... The old lame Kitty smiles. She turns her head showcasing her face from different angles.
What..? What...? Oh my God. Did you have something “done?";
Just an itsy-bitsy thing..
Fuck off. You look exactly the same as you did last year.  29.
That’s the idea. A little bit goes a long way. Not that you need it you beautiful motherfucker. Adelaide quietly doesn’t accept the compliment. She looks around the beach.
Stop. I can already tell the things you think are flaws are so annoying. Adelaide almost says something, but doesn’t.
What?
Nothing.
I'm kidding. Tell me...
Sometimes I have a hard time... talking.
You ever wonder “what if... What if things had happened differently?”
I don’t know what you mean?

You mean the What-if-I-never-got- married-and-had-kids question? Um, yeah. I’m having it literally right now. Trust me. The girls have just gotten to the age where I feel like I can finally go to the spa once a week for ‘me time.’
“Me time?” What’s that?
It’s mandatory.  30. DOWN BY THE WATER... Becca approaches Jason. Lindsey does cartwheels. She land the sand structure he’s making.
(to Jason) Oops. Oh shit! My bad. Lindsey continues cartwheeling back and forth.
It doesn’t matter. Becca offers Jason the kite reel.
Wanna try? It’s pretty dumb, but you might like it.
Um. Okay.
The wind’s good. Jason tries to fly the kite. Lyndsey cartwheels over to Z who reads on the beach.
Your brother's so weird.
He just has a problem focusing. They look over at Jason who tries to fly the kite while watching his own hand snap.
Are you going in the water..?
I’m good.
Why not? Jason gets up and walks away from the water.
Where are you going?
To the bathroom.  31.
Why don’t you pee in the ocean?
Jinx.
Kitty and Adelaide don’t notice.
You ever wish you kept dancing?
Sometimes.
I mean you were, like, really good right?
I peaked at fourteen.
Didn’t we all? Jason passes by them as he heads towards the Port-O-Potti

Jason takes a long walk past sunbathers and other people the port-o-potty near the boardwalk, becoming increasingl remote from the group. When he arrives at the port-o-pott sour older lady emerges. He lets her pass and then goes inside.
Adelaide continues with Kitty.
There was this one competition where I did a piece from “The Nutcracker”...
I love “The Nutcracker.”  32.
You know the ‘Grand Pas de Deux’? It’s the pretty one, at the end of the ballet.
Oh! Where she flies into the prince’s arms.
Yeah.
Okay, can I tell you? I cry at that part every time. Josh interrupts from afar.
You cry? Really?
(To Josh) No one’s talking to you. (To Adelaide) You were saying...
The ‘Grand Pas’ is supposed to be a dance for two, but I turned it into a solo.
Um... that’s badass.
Nerve-racking. I thought I’d get disqualified, but when I finished the audience went crazy. I won first prize. It was the best moment of my life...besides Zora and Jason's birth.

The girls don’t make my top ten, by the way. I’m convinced I would be a movie star if I didn’t have them at exactly the wrong time... Adelaide starts watching people on the beach around them Kitty drones on. A guy chases his girlfriend who screams. small group of people laugh hard. A teen play fights with brother. Each vignette seems to make Adelaide increasingl nervous but she hides it well.  33.

...I trained at Stella Adler and booked two commercials before I met Josh, and totally stopped auditioning when I got preggers. Then the move to San Fransisco was like a fucking career killer. The whole thing was supposed to be I would fly out for auditions but that never happened. I put myself on tape for like half a year, but it’s really not the same. You have to be in the room for things to fall into place. A red frisbee falls onto the towel they’re sitting on. Adelaide is startled.

Jesus! (To Adelaide) Oh, look. Adelaide looks down. The frisbee has landed perfectly on of the towel’s large, printed polka dots. Adelaide picks up, revealing the same colored dot underneath. It really eerily perfect. Adelaide is quietly concerned.
Whoa. That’s crazy. We’ve been having so many weird coincidences happening lately. A guy runs over to claim the frisbee. Adelaide gives it t him.
Thanks. He leaves. Adelaide looks over and sees the twins playing near Zora. No Jason.
No “I'm sorry”? Dick. Anyway, we should go back to our place. I think it’s ‘vodka ‘o clock.’
Where’s Jason?  34.

Jason comes out of the port-o-potty and starts walking ba to the beach but stops when he notices something strange. man stands facing away from him on the beach about twenty yards away. The man has his arms stretched out at his sid in a relaxed manner, like a yoga pose. Other people walk around him, only occasionally noticing him. Jason is transfixed. He walks slowly and wide around the man tryin see his face. It’s tense.
Adelaide looks around with increasing concern.
Where’s Jason?
(looking) He's...

Once upon a time, there was a girl, and the girl had a shadow. The two were connected; tethered together. So whatever happened to the girl happened to the shadow...
